title: Big 12 Power Rankings: Clear contenders emerge in conference race
text:
CLOSE USA TODAY Sports' Paul Myerberg breaks down the latest Amway Coaches Poll. USA TODAY

Week 7 of the college football season gave us what we were waiting for.

Oklahoma showed it is the strength of the Big 12 Conference. Texas didn’t do anything to warrant thinking the Longhorns are anything other than a strong No. 2, and yes, Baylor is for real — although the officials may have had something to do with the Bears’ latest escape by three points over Texas Tech.

Throw in Iowa State, which after almost two months finally looks to have found a bonafide rushing threat not named Brock Purdy, and you’ve got a clear picture of the conference’s top four teams.

No. 1 Oklahoma (6-0, 3-0 Big 12)

Last week’s ranking: 1

Last weekend: Defeated No. 11 Texas 34-27.

In a nutshell: Breaking News — Oklahoma is playing solid defense, too. Allowing just 27 points in what’s usually a high-scoring Red River Showdown shows that finally, the Sooners can play a bit on that side of the ball. They had to, because quarterback Jalen Hurts wasn’t perfect – with a fumble and a red-zone interception. He’s still in serious Heisman Trophy contention.

On deck: Saturday vs. West Virginia at noon, Fox.

Oklahoma quarterback Jalen Hurts (1) wears the Golden Hat trophy after the Sooners defeated Texas at the Cotton Bowl. (Photo: Matthew Emmons, USA TODAY Sports)

No. 2 Texas (4-2, 2-1)

Last week’s ranking: 2

Last weekend: Lost to Oklahoma 34-27.

In a nutshell: This is a very good program that’s still a way from being elite. Get an offensive line that doesn’t give up nine sacks – like it did against Oklahoma on Saturday. Get an offensive line that can keep defenders at least out of the backfield and somewhat away from quarterback Sam Ehlinger ... that’s when this program becomes elite.

On deck: Saturday vs. Kansas, 7 p.m., Longhorn Network.

No. 3 Baylor (6-0, 3-0)

Last week’s ranking: 3

Last weekend: Defeated Texas Tech 33-30 in two overtimes.

In a nutshell: Living on the edge is one thing — like the Bears have done recently against Texas Tech and Iowa State — but doing it going forward without one of its star players could be tough. Linebacker Clay Johnston is likely to miss the remainder of the season because of a knee injury suffered in the double-overtime win against the Red Raiders. He was the team leader in tackles for a team that’s been playing solid defense.

On deck: Saturday at Oklahoma State, 4 p.m., Fox.

No. 4 Iowa State (4-2, 2-1)

Last week’s ranking: 4

Last weekend: Defeated West Virginia 38-14.

In a nutshell: Breaking News II: The Cyclones have found a running back. True freshman Breece Hall answered the call with 132 rushing yards and three touchdowns on 26 carries Saturday. The only thing holding him back from being No. 1 earlier, was inconsistent practices. He’s clearly on top of the depth chart moving forward.

On deck: Saturday at Texas Tech, noon, FS1.

No. 5 TCU (3-2, 1-1)

Last week’s ranking: 8

Last weekend: Idle.

In a nutshell: An off-week was exactly what TCU needed. True freshman quarterback Max Duggan needed a Saturday in which to catch his breath, after his whirlwind first year out of a Council Bluffs, Iowa high school. Big test this week comes in Manhattan.

On deck: Saturday at Kansas State, 2:30 p.m., FSN.

No. 6 Oklahoma State (4-2, 1-2)

Last week’s ranking: 6

Last weekend: Idle.

In a nutshell: Now it gets tough for an Oklahoma State team that’s lost two of its last three games. The Cowboys are at home against Baylor on Saturday, followed by at Iowa State, and then back home for TCU.

On deck: Saturday vs. No. 18 Baylor, 4 p.m., Fox

No. 7 Texas Tech (3-3, 1-2)

Last week’s ranking: 5

Last weekend: Lost to Baylor 33-30 in two overtimes.

In a nutshell: How close did Texas Tech come to upsetting a second ranked opponent in a row? Very, considering in incorrect ref’s decision during the first overtime erased a Red Raiders fumble recovery in the double-overtime loss. On the first OT’s second play, Tech’s Jaylon Hutchings recovered a faulty snap, however the refs ruled it to be an illegal snap, and penalized the Bears five yards. Naturally, they went on to score during the controversial possession.

On deck: Saturday vs. Iowa State, noon, FS1.

No. 8 Kansas State (3-2, 0-2)

Last week’s ranking: 9

Last weekend: Idle.

In a nutshell: Coach Chris Klieman’s team has lost two Big 12 games in a row after going 3-0 in the non-conference season. With Oklahoma and Texas still to play, time could be running out in reaching the six-win bowl game plateau.

On deck: Saturday vs. TCU, 2:30 p.m., FSN.

No. 9 West Virginia (3-3, 1-2)

Last week’s ranking: 7

Last weekend: Lost to Iowa State 38-14.

In a nutshell: The Mountaineers are a 33-point underdog at Oklahoma Saturday for a game in which they could be without a healthy quarterback Austin Kendall, and in which starting cornerback Hakeem Bailey is suspended for the first half after being flagged for targeting against Iowa State

On deck: Saturday at No. 5 Oklahoma, noon, Fox.

No. 10 Kansas (2-4, 0-3)

Last week’s ranking: 10

Last weekend: Idle.

In a nutshell: The off-week was good for the offensively-poor team to adjust to the recent hiring of new coordinator Brent Dearmon. His mission is to pump life into unit that’s averaging just 354.5 yards. That’s 103rd nationally, yet still ahead of West Virginia in the Big 12.

On deck: Saturday at Texas at 7 p.m., Longhorn Network.
description: After Week 7, the picture of who are the contenders in the Big 12 is clear. Oklahoma looks elite. Texas is strong No. 2. Iowa State and Baylor are good.
